commit_message:
db: Make EngineFacade a Facade

This blueprint proposes a new declarative
system of connection management and
session and transaction scoping for
all projects that currently make use
of oslo.db.session.EngineFacade.

Change-Id: I8c0efa3b859c2fe5f06f4c0416c5323362d7ef72
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/81/125181/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================ Make EngineFacade into a Facade ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/make-enginefacade-a-facade Problem description =================== The oslo.db.sqlalchemy.session.EngineFacade class serves as the gateway to SQLAlchemy Engine and Session availability within many OpenStack projects, including Ceilometer, Glance, Heat, Ironic, Keystone, Neutron, Nova, and Sahara. However, the object barely serves any purpose, as while it provides a function call that ultimately calls ``create_engine()`` and ``sessionmaker()``, consuming projects receive almost no utility from this object, and instead invent their own systems, all of which are different, verbose, and error prone, with varying degrees performance, stability, and scalability issues. In the first case, EngineFacade as used by projects needs to act as a thread-safe registry, a feature which it does not provide in any way. As a result, consuming projects have all invented an ad-hoc set of boilerplate code to achieve this, and not consistently. For example, in Keystone, the EngineFacade is created thusly in keystone/common/sql/core.py:: _engine_facade = None def _get_engine_facade(): global _engine_facade if not _engine_facade: _engine_facade = db_session.EngineFacade.from_config(CONF) return _engine_facade In Ironic we have this; Sahara contains something similar:: _FACADE = None def _create_facade_lazily(): global _FACADE if _FACADE is None: _FACADE = db_session.EngineFacade( CONF.database.connection, **dict(CONF.database.iteritems()) ) return _FACADE However in Nova, we get a similar pattern but with one very critical twist:: _ENGINE_FACADE = None _LOCK = threading.Lock() def _create_facade_lazily(): global _LOCK, _ENGINE_FACADE if _ENGINE_FACADE is None: with _LOCK: if _ENGINE_FACADE is None: _ENGINE_FACADE = db_session.EngineFacade.from_config(CONF) return _ENGINE_FACADE Each library invents their own system of establishing EngineFacade as a singleton, and providing CONF into it; none of which are alike. Nova happened to discover that this singleton pattern isn't threadsafe, and added a mutex, however the lack of this critical improvement remains a bug in all the other systems. Adding a consistent ``get_facade()`` method is an easy win here, but the problem goes beyond that. EngineFacade ends its work at ``get_engine()`` or ``get_session()``; the former returns a SQLAlchemy Engine object, which itself is only a factory for connections, and the latter returns a SQLAlchemy Session object, ready for use but otherwise unassociated with any specific connection or transactional context. What we have is essentially only a factory, and not a facade. The definition of "facade" is a layer that conceals the use of fine-grained APIs behind a layer that is coarse-grained and tailored to the use case at hand; EngineFacade provides no such functionality. The harm caused by this lack of leadership on EngineFacade's part is widespread. Failing to provide an adequate creational pattern above leads individual Openstack projects to invent their own half-adequate and repetitive systems; but by failing to provide any guidance on connectivity or transactional scope, all Openstack projects have gone on to invent these systems as well. In most cases these abstraction systems are inconsistent, inadequate and misunderstood, and ultimately are leading to mis-use of engines, sessions, and transactions on a wide scale, often having direct consequences for performance, stability and scalability. For a brief tour, we first show Neutron's system, which is the most organized. Neutron has a system where all database operations proceed where a nova.context.Context object is passed; the Context object serves as home base to a SQLAlchemy Session that was ultimately retrieved from EngineFacade. A method excerpt looks like this:: def add_resource_association(self, context, service_type, provider_name, resource_id): # ... with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): assoc = ProviderResourceAssociation(provider_name=provider_name, resource_id=resource_id) context.session.add(assoc) We see that while the Context object at least allows that all operations are given access to the same Session, the method still has to state that it wishes to begin a transaction, and that it needs to support the fact that the Session may already be within a transaction. Neutron's system is a little verbose, and suffers from the issue that individual methods called in series may invoke their work within distinct transactions, but at least allows a series of nested operations to proceed on the same transaction. Next we look at Keystone. Keystone's system looks nice but in reality is using resources on an ad-hoc basis:: @sql.handle_conflicts(conflict_type='trust') def list_trusts(self): session = sql.get_session() trusts = session.query(TrustModel).filter_by(deleted_at=None) return [trust_ref.to_dict() for trust_ref in trusts] Above, the ``sql.get_session()`` call is just another call to EngineFacade.get_session(). The ``sql.handle_conflicts()`` call doesn't have any role in establishing this session. The above call also uses the SQLAlchemy Session in "autocommit" mode; in this mode, SQLAlchemy essentially creates connection/transaction context on a per-query basis, and discards it at the end. It's a very inefficient way to use the Session and is explicitly unrecommended in the documentation. Keystone methods essentially make an explicit choice if they wish to use ``session.begin()`` or not, based on if they call ``sql.get_session()`` or ``sql.transaction()``. The misunderstanding here is that the Python Database API (DBAPI) *always* uses a transaction, and by Keystone switching between ``get_session()`` or ``transaction()`` merely establishes smaller transactions in the former case, wasting database resources as well as lots of Python overhead involved with the SQLAlchemy Session's management of this transactional state, not to mention that of the Session itself. Wihtin Nova, the connectivity system is more less equivalent to that of Keystone; many explicit calls to get_session() and heavy use of the session in "autocommit" mode, most commonly through the model_query() function. But more critical is that the complexity of Nova's API without a foolproof system of maintaining transaction scope leads to a widespread use of multiple transactions per API call, in some cases concurrently, which has definite stability and performance implications. A typical Nova method looks like:: @require_admin_context def cell_update(context, cell_name, values): session = get_session() with session.begin(): cell_query = _cell_get_by_name_query(context, cell_name, session=session) if not cell_query.update(values): raise exception.CellNotFound(cell_name=cell_name) cell = cell_query.first() return cell In the above call, the ``get_session()`` call returns a brand new session upon which a transaction is begun; the method then calls into ``_cell_get_by_name_query``, passing in the Session in an effort to ensure this sub-method uses the same transaction. The intent here is good, that the ``cell_update()`` method knows it should share its transactional context with a sub-method. However, this is a burdensome and verbose coding pattern which is inconsistently applied. In those areas where it fails to be applied, the end result is that a single operation invokes several new connections and transactions, sometimes within a nested set of calls; this is wasteful and slow and is a key risk factor for deadlocks. Examples of non-nested, multiple connection/session use within a single call are easy to find. Truly nested transactions are less frequent; one is nova/db/api.py -> floating_ip_bulk_destroy. In this method, we see:: @require_context def floating_ip_bulk_destroy(context, ips): session = get_session() with session.begin(): project_id_to_quota_count = collections.defaultdict(int) for ip_block in _ip_range_splitter(ips): query = model_query(context, models.FloatingIp).\ filter(models.FloatingIp.address.in_(ip_block)).\ filter_by(auto_assigned=False) rows = query.all() for row in rows: project_id_to_quota_count[row['project_id']] -= 1 model_query(context, models.FloatingIp).\ filter(models.FloatingIp.address.in_(ip_block)).\ soft_delete(synchronize_session='fetch') for project_id, count in project_id_to_quota_count.iteritems(): try: reservations = quota.QUOTAS.reserve(context, project_id=project_id, floating_ips=count) quota.QUOTAS.commit(context, reservations, project_id=project_id) except Exception: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.exception(_("Failed to update usages bulk " "deallocating floating IP")) The entire method is within ``session.begin()``. But within that, we first see a two calls to ``model_query()``, each of which forget to pass the session along, so ``model_query()`` makes it's own session and transaction for each. In the first place, it's ``model_query()``s ability to even do this ("more than one way to do it") that allows for this mistake to go missed. But even more seriously, ``get_session()`` is called many times again, without any way of passing a session through, down below when ``quota.QUOTAS.commit`` is called within a loop. The interface for this starts outside of the database API, in nova/quota.py, where no ``session`` argument is available:: def commit(self, context, reservations, project_id=None, user_id=None): """Commit reservations.""" if project_id is None: project_id = context.project_id # If user_id is None, then we use the user_id in context if user_id is None: user_id = context.user_id db.reservation_commit(context, reservations, project_id=project_id, user_id=user_id) And then ``db.reservation_commit`` is back in nova/db/api.py, where we see a whole new call to ``get_session()``, ``begin()`` and we even see a whole repetition of the ``@_retry_on_deadlock`` decorator:: @require_context @_retry_on_deadlock def reservation_commit(context, reservations, project_id=None, user_id=None): session = get_session() with session.begin(): _project_usages, user_usages = _get_project_user_quota_usages( context, session, project_id, user_id) reservation_query = _quota_reservations_query(session, context, reservations) for reservation in reservation_query.all(): usage = user_usages[reservation.resource] if reservation.delta >= 0: usage.reserved -= reservation.delta usage.in_use += reservation.delta reservation_query.soft_delete(synchronize_session=False) In the above example, we first see that the "ad-hoc-session" system leads to coding errors in the case of ``model_query()``, but in the case of ``reservation_commit()``, the architecture itself disallows correct propagation of the transation and Session. Examples of non-nested multiple sessions and transactions in one API call are prevalent, and can be found by using an assertion within the test suite. Examples include: * instance_create() calls get_session(), then ec2_instance_create() -> models.save() -> get_session() * instance_create() calls get_session(), then ec2_instance_create() -> models.save() -> get_session() * aggregate_create() calls get_session(), then aggregate_get() -> model_query() -> get_session() The above examples can all be fixed manually by adding more "session" arguments and checking for transactions in progress, but these issues are all preventable by providing a facade that handles this scoping automatically. Proposed change =============== <sneak peek: it'll be a decorator that does everything, get_session(), the transaction, etc. it will also do functions like retry_on_deadlock. The Session or Engine will be delivered into the argument list by the decorator, which is the first controversial aspect. All projects will need to deliver this decorator to all methods that want DB connectivity, with the possible exception of Neutron which already has a context, but we'd still want to remove the begin() calls from it>. Alternatives ------------ Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- Security impact --------------- Performance Impact ------------------ Configuration Impact -------------------- Developer Impact ---------------- Testing Impact -------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Work Items ---------- Incubation ========== Adoption -------- Library ------- Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- Documentation Impact ==================== Dependencies ============ References ========== .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

subject: Ensure dir permissions are 755 for cleanup to work
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-20 20:57:20.000000000', 'files': ['functions.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/5f5db507e5af73877a6a7500bb042af27b567a8b', 'message': 'Ensure dir permissions are 755 for cleanup to work

cleanup_host uses wildcards to copy several files. For example,

  sudo cp /etc/sudoers.d/* $BASE/logs/sudoers.d/

This wildcard expansion would not work if the sudoers.d does not
have read permission for others. The lack of permission would result
in "cp: cannot stat ..." error when a wildcard is used. This error
can currently be seen for sudoers.d in devstack-gate-cleanup-host.txt

With this patch we fix the permissions so that the expansion works for
/etc/sudoers.d and for /var/log/libvirtd/.

The latter is not needed on Ubuntu, but fixes similar issue on
Fedora 20. We do not use is_fedora check because it would just add
clutter, and the permission fix does not have any side effects as we
are cleaning up.

Further permission fixes could be necessary and this patch is in no
way covers all the cases.

Change-Id: Ia068c2356ad6fa27052ef4b38d1a95701f7cf6ac
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure dir permissions are 755 for cleanup to work

cleanup_host uses wildcards to copy several files. For example,

  sudo cp /etc/sudoers.d/* $BASE/logs/sudoers.d/

This wildcard expansion would not work if the sudoers.d does not
have read permission for others. The lack of permission would result
in "cp: cannot stat ..." error when a wildcard is used. This error
can currently be seen for sudoers.d in devstack-gate-cleanup-host.txt

With this patch we fix the permissions so that the expansion works for
/etc/sudoers.d and for /var/log/libvirtd/.

The latter is not needed on Ubuntu, but fixes similar issue on
Fedora 20. We do not use is_fedora check because it would just add
clutter, and the permission fix does not have any side effects as we
are cleaning up.

Further permission fixes could be necessary and this patch is in no
way covers all the cases.

Change-Id: Ia068c2356ad6fa27052ef4b38d1a95701f7cf6ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/30/129730/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ensure proper permissions for wildcard expansion to work sudo find /var/log/libvirt -type d -exec chmod 755 {} + # Ensure proper permissions for wildcard expansion to work sudo chmod 755 /etc/sudoers.d

revisions:

Certain prerequisites are not found by yum by default on RHEL. The yum
command specified in the RHEL instructions for installing prerequisites
fails to install python-pip and git-review. Adding a sentence directing
readers to use the EPEL software repository which has the missing

commit_message:
Adds help for installing prerequisites on RHEL

Certain prerequisites are not found by yum by default on RHEL. The yum
command specified in the RHEL instructions for installing prerequisites
fails to install python-pip and git-review. Adding a sentence directing
readers to use the EPEL software repository which has the missing
packages.

Closes-Bug: 1392355
Change-Id: I6ff44773d4a0850c64f0eddc808164c3f91ef429
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/99/135399/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If using RHEL and yum reports No package python-pip available and No package git-review available, use the EPEL software repository. Instructions can be found at `<http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/EPEL/FAQ#howtouse>`_.

commit_message:
Improved error handling in kafka_consumer

If the kafka_consumer plugin encounters an error fetching consumer offsets
(like for a partition which is configured but no longer exists), it can
start to allocate threads and never close them oout.  I added additional
exception handling around fetching both consumer and broker offsets so
that the plugin will log errors, but not fail altogether, and not cause
runaway thread usage.

Change-Id: I03e6f7cc3ecd787d7b4ad54b74136540607a465a

subject: Add pycrypto install to swift-proxy element
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-18 13:55:08.000000000', 'files': ['elements/swift-proxy/install.d/swift-source-install/76-swift-proxy'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/dfb795c79008217b19484e22b73977d8d63395d2', 'message': "Add pycrypto install to swift-proxy element

We've encountered an issue with memcache encryption of authtoken
entries on Swift proxies where the authtoken middleware errors
out since pycrypto isn't installed.  This has been exposed on
standalone Swift servers.  To fix the issue, we've modified the

Closes-Bug: #1393790

commit_message:
Add pycrypto install to swift-proxy element

We've encountered an issue with memcache encryption of authtoken
entries on Swift proxies where the authtoken middleware errors
out since pycrypto isn't installed.  This has been exposed on
standalone Swift servers.  To fix the issue, we've modified the
swift-proxy element so that pycrypto is installed along with
keystonemiddleware and python-swiftclient.

Change-Id: I727087a85df7ed94fd0ecac86c78826328e644f4
Closes-Bug: #1393790
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/88/135288/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $SWIFT_VENV_DIR/bin/pip install pycrypto

subject: Do not create a tenant for network quota tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-24 21:44:47.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/api/network/admin/test_quotas.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/e4e07e5e061e15fd8613c3e27f12c3424b8e68a1', 'message': 'Do not create a tenant for network quota tests

Neutron does not validate the tenant id passed to the quota
extension with Keystone. This means that it is not necessary
to create a tenant before performing these tests.

This patch remove tenant/creation deletion code, thus simplifying
the test itself. It also ensures the cleanup action for tenant
quotas is executed once. The second execution indeed would just
remove a record which has already been removed.
The above condition does not return an error because neutron
return a 204 response in this case.

Change-Id: I698cfd33bffcb5712fd613a81712e4b31f460ec4
'}]
commit_message:
Do not create a tenant for network quota tests

Neutron does not validate the tenant id passed to the quota
extension with Keystone. This means that it is not necessary
to create a tenant before performing these tests.

This patch remove tenant/creation deletion code, thus simplifying
the test itself. It also ensures the cleanup action for tenant
quotas is executed once. The second execution indeed would just
remove a record which has already been removed.
The above condition does not return an error because neutron
return a 204 response in this case.

Change-Id: I698cfd33bffcb5712fd613a81712e4b31f460ec4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/60/123860/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Generate a uuid to simulate a tenant # For quota tests the tenant does not have to actually exist in # the identity service as neutron does not validate tenant ids tenant_id = data_utils.rand_uuid()
deleted_lines: cls.identity_admin_client = cls.os_adm.identity_client # Add a tenant to conduct the test test_tenant = data_utils.rand_name('test_tenant_') test_description = data_utils.rand_name('desc_') _, tenant = self.identity_admin_client.create_tenant( name=test_tenant, description=test_description) tenant_id = tenant['id'] self.addCleanup(self.identity_admin_client.delete_tenant, tenant_id) self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.reset_quotas, tenant_id)

commit_message:
Add --or-show support for v3 identity resources

Add --or-show for the following:
  * v3 roles
  * v3 projects
  * v3 domains
  * v3 users
  * v3 groups

Closes-Bug: #1390389
Change-Id: Id4ef043e5fda6be49a515eb3fe138c813c393ec9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/52/134452/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystoneclient.openstack.common.apiclient import exceptions as ksc_excfrom openstackclient.i18n import _ # noqa parser.add_argument( '--or-show', action='store_true', help=_('Return existing domain'), ) try: domain = identity_client.domains.create( name=parsed_args.name, description=parsed_args.description, enabled=parsed_args.enabled, ) except ksc_exc.Conflict as e: if parsed_args.or_show: domain = utils.find_resource(identity_client.domains, parsed_args.name) self.log.info('Returning existing domain %s', domain.name) else: raise e

Install the required packages on openSUSE when creating images.

commit_message:
Fix config options deprecated in Juno

http://docs.openstack.org/juno/config-reference/content/keystone-conf-changes-juno.html

Change-Id: I7ba69ca616bd7ae772b0a45a9fda5910fd66071c

commit_message:
logging: Give greater flexibility for log configuration

This patch aims to provide the deployer a greater flexibility
when it comes to logging. The deployer can specify the log format
he wants and the date format for those logs.

Change-Id: I637ad0a49cd21ff870b0bee010c088da8e179c9e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer refs/changes/55/106055/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: context 'with custom log format' do before { params.merge!( :logging_context_format => '%(levelname)s %(name)s', :logging_exception_format => '%(levelname)s %(name)s', :logging_default_format => '%(levelname)s %(name)s', :log_date_format => '%Y-%M-%d' ) } it { should contain_ceilometer_config('DEFAULT/logging_context_format').with_value('%(levelname)s %(name)s') } it { should contain_ceilometer_config('DEFAULT/logging_exception_format').with_value('%(levelname)s %(name)s') } it { should contain_ceilometer_config('DEFAULT/logging_default_format').with_value('%(levelname)s %(name)s') } it { should contain_ceilometer_config('DEFAULT/log_date_format').with_value('%Y-%M-%d') } end

commit_message:
Adds container quotas headers

Documents X-container-meta-quota-bytes and X-container-meta-quota-count headers.

Change-Id: Ib743e40ddcdfdcdb73016f4a2c3809f29d1e9d87
Closes-bug:1090653
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/31/135131/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <!ENTITY container-meta-quota-bytesHeader ' <param xmlns="http://wadl.dev.java.net/2009/02" name="X-Container-Read" style="header" required="false" type="xsd:string"> <wadl:doc xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:wadl="http://wadl.dev.java.net/2009/02" xml:lang="EN"> <para>Sets maximum size of the container, in bytes. Typically these values are set by an administrator. Returns a 413 response (request entity too large) when an object PUT operation exceeds this quota value.</para> </wadl:doc> </param>'> <!ENTITY container-meta-quota-countHeader ' <param xmlns="http://wadl.dev.java.net/2009/02" name="X-Container-Read" style="header" required="false" type="xsd:string"> <wadl:doc xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:wadl="http://wadl.dev.java.net/2009/02" xml:lang="EN"> <para>Sets maximum object count of the container. commit_message:
Tag all nova packages

Some users wish to override the default package provider by their own.

Tag all packages with the 'openstack' and its corresponding
service name to allow mass resource attributes override using
resource collectors.

Change-Id: I3a8041be7b9fcb304d2cf0dbdd4a021cd8594c02
Closes-bug: #1391209
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/91/134291/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update [neutron] section in nova.conf for Juno

Use new parameters for Juno like it's documented here:
http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/nova-conf-changes-master.html

* Use [neutron] section
* Delete the neutron_prefix when needed

Closes-bug #1391099

Change-Id: Ib63a80ea28b5aa5c033df3ec503031a99f4824c9

Now that resource.prop objects have a default value, allow that value to

'}]
commit_message:
Add the ability to set a new default for props

Now that resource.prop objects have a default value, allow that value to
be set by callers. The default remains as None.

Change-Id: Id5a5bb3ecf14664793f42c945eb6b49b077e9e64
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/33/135433/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_defaults(self): new_default = 100 class Test(resource.Resource): attr1 = resource.prop("attr1") attr2 = resource.prop("attr2", default=new_default) t = Test() self.assertIsNone(t.attr1) self.assertEqual(t.attr2, new_default)

subject: remove python-heatclient from integrated gate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-18 21:09:02.000000000', 'files': ['zuul/layout.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/a7d23954464ddd6f7ad0b76bca4ec828b1e59183', 'message': "remove python-heatclient from integrated gate

apparently when cleaning up the python-*clients to not be in the
integrated gate, I missed removing that from heatclient. In the libs
from pypi world the integrated gate jobs don't do what you think they
do, and the source jobs are really the important ones.

Will also let python-heatclient merge code faster as it will be
decoupled from the integrated gate pipeline.

Change-Id: I45bb269d700cbd9cdf90b6b9d99df18ded444fdf
"}]
commit_message:
remove python-heatclient from integrated gate

apparently when cleaning up the python-*clients to not be in the
integrated gate, I missed removing that from heatclient. In the libs
from pypi world the integrated gate jobs don't do what you think they
do, and the source jobs are really the important ones.

Will also let python-heatclient merge code faster as it will be
decoupled from the integrated gate pipeline.

Change-Id: I45bb269d700cbd9cdf90b6b9d99df18ded444fdf

commit_message:
Allow a subtranslator to use a field from the parent table as an id

In the previous version, a subtranslator always computed a new id based on the
subtable's content.  This change allows a subtranslator to use a column from
the parent table in the subtable's id column.

For example, the following translator:
  list_translator = {'translation-type': 'LIST',
                     'table-name': 'subtable',
                     'parent-key': 'foreign-key',
                     'val-col': 'val_col',
                     'translator': self.value_trans}
  translator = {'translation-type': 'HDICT', 'table-name': 'testtable',
                'selector-type': 'DICT_SELECTOR',
                'field-translators': ({'fieldname': 'foreign-key',
                                       'translator': self.value_trans},
                                      {'fieldname': 'foo',
                                       'translator': list_translator})}

Would turn the following objects
 {'foreign-key': 100, 'foo': (1, 2)}
 {'foreign-key': 101, 'foo': (3, 4)}

into these tables:

  testtable  subtable
  100        100, 1
  101        100, 2
             101, 3
             101, 4

Change-Id: I5b337c9bf7ba3af3ecf7732215cba38b6f923a95
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/88/133888/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'parent-key': 'parent_key_column', with 'None'. If 'parent-key' is specified, the translator prepend a value from the parent translator as the first column of this table. For example, if the parent table already has a unique key named 'id', then setting 'parent-key': 'id' will populate each row in the child table with the foreign unique key from the parent. If 'id-col' is specified, the translator will prepend a unique id column to each row where the id's value is the hash of the remaining columns for that row. Using both parent-key and id-col at the same time is redudant, so DataSourceDriver will reject that configuration. 'parent-key': 'parent_key_column', If the VDICT's subtranslator specifies the parent-key, the parent-key must be the VDICT's value column due to an implementation choice. The id column is not available until after the subtranslator runs. 'udevadm'.  It is passed as an argument with an absolute directory path
which can vary on each linux install.  By removing the directory path,
it will find this utility by way of the user's environment path since

commit_message:
Execute udevadm on other linux installs

When ofa and ovs neutron agents start, they use the linux utility
'udevadm'.  It is passed as an argument with an absolute directory path
which can vary on each linux install.  By removing the directory path,
it will find this utility by way of the user's environment path since
linux executables are configured in each user's path upon user creation.

Change-Id: I2344290d38c7889b8f32d8fb9c5161b09826e037
Closes-bug:  #1367697

subject: Disable Cgsnapshot APIs by default
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-18 04:58:03.000000000', 'files': ['etc/cinder/policy.json'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/95a39d9c326fd218c835c3387380c094efad7a99', 'message': 'Disable Cgsnapshot APIs by default

Currently consistency group APIs are disabled by default because there are
only a very small number of drivers that have implemented them. In
cinder/etc/cinder/policy.json, there are the following entries:

    "consistencygroup:create" : "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:delete": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get_all": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:create_cgsnapshot" : "",
    "consistencygroup:delete_cgsnapshot": "",
    "consistencygroup:get_cgsnapshot": "",
    "consistencygroup:get_all_cgsnapshots": "",

Note that Cgsnapshot related APIs are not disabled by default. They should be
disabled to be consistent. So the policy entries will be changed to the
following in this patch:

    "consistencygroup:create" : "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:delete": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get_all": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:create_cgsnapshot" : "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:delete_cgsnapshot": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get_cgsnapshot": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get_all_cgsnapshots": "group:nobody",

Note: If a driver has CG functions implemented, the CG APIs have to be enabled
by changing "group:nobody" to "" for the CG functions to work.

Change-Id: If59b3da1e84e25e1f547793638c58966e10f488c
Closes-Bug: #1393652
'}]
commit_message:
Disable Cgsnapshot APIs by default

Currently consistency group APIs are disabled by default because there are
only a very small number of drivers that have implemented them. In
cinder/etc/cinder/policy.json, there are the following entries:

    "consistencygroup:create" : "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:delete": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get_all": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:create_cgsnapshot" : "",
    "consistencygroup:delete_cgsnapshot": "",
    "consistencygroup:get_cgsnapshot": "",
    "consistencygroup:get_all_cgsnapshots": "",

Note that Cgsnapshot related APIs are not disabled by default. They should be
disabled to be consistent. So the policy entries will be changed to the
following in this patch:

    "consistencygroup:create" : "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:delete": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get_all": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:create_cgsnapshot" : "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:delete_cgsnapshot": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get_cgsnapshot": "group:nobody",
    "consistencygroup:get_all_cgsnapshots": "group:nobody",

Note: If a driver has CG functions implemented, the CG APIs have to be enabled
by changing "group:nobody" to "" for the CG functions to work.

Change-Id: If59b3da1e84e25e1f547793638c58966e10f488c
Closes-Bug: #1393652

commit_message:
Prefer X-Backend-Timestamp for X-Newest

When a X-Backend-Timestamp is available it would generally preferred
over a less specific value and sorts correctly against any X-Timestamp
values anyway.

Change-Id: I08b7eb37ab8bd6eb3afbb7dee44ed07a8c69b57e

commit_message:
Fix shutdown in the case the entire machine is going down.

Change-Id: Idaf19e5703886029e05e95ac5a7175eb9346762c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-thresh refs/changes/17/135417/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #! /bin/bash # On system shutdown storm is being shutdown also and this will hang so skip shutting down thresh in that case if [ -e '/sbin/runlevel' ]; then # upstart/sysV case if [ `runlevel | cut -d\ -f 2` == 0 ]; then exit 0 fi else # systemd case systemctl list-units --type=target |grep shutdown.target if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then exit 0 fi fi

commit_message:
Move puppet-monasca to Stackforge

puppet-monasca from Time Warner Cable repository to Stackforge which
will be supported by the puppet-openstack community.  This patch will
integrate the puppet module in the OpenStack infrastructure
workflow.

Change-Id: I9250933bdc11f5a2b3478293318aa097ceb1b24d

commit_message:
Use entry_points to load services in UserPreference

Instead of copying and pasting the same three lines of code for each
service let's rely on entry points defined in setup.cfg.

Change-Id: I932fb3e8ef6c93a422489704622ed86bf20d22f0

commit_message:
Fix a problem in creating consistency group in ProphetStor driver.

a.Failed to create CG in the storage:
  Storage site cannot accept CG uuid including "-" word. Before
  sending API to back-end storage, the "-" word in the CG uuid
  needs to be removed.
b.Failed to delete volume of CG:
  Corrected api leaving group operation key.

Change-Id: I017b2f65c4da6961219f0b972edae2b1cb447878
Closes-Bug: 1391724

deleted_lines: metadata['volume_group_operation'] = 'level' ret, output = self.dpl.create_vg(group['id'], group['name'], group['description'])

commit_message:
Allow IPA to be cloned and built

Currently jobs are failing due to "Cloning not allowed in this
configuration". This is an attempt to get past this configuration error.

Change-Id: I6f84f698763912042ff5ec93f827008802d4e80f

commit_message:
Delete console negative tests

These autogenerated tests are wrong in at least 2 ways, one is
assumptions about when servers are available, and the other a schema
which makes assumptions about the resource end points that are
provably wrong when you look at the Nova code (which is unchanged for
2 years).

It's not clear there is any value generated from these tests, suggest
to delete them.

Related-Bug: #1392860

Change-Id: I4822546f73055e307017960bd470333c81cdea01

subject: Fix unit tests to detect import failures
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-16 15:37:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/95cdc28eab9fd2dd66aca6ec6b91163462a660d7', 'message': "Add a unit test to detect import failures

This commit adds a new unit test to tempest which simply runs
'testr list-tests' to run discovery on tempest. This is done to ensure
that from a bare tempest repo with the requirements all present we can
actually import and list all the tests. Historically this has been an
issue so adding a test to enforce it moving forward should prevent it

commit_message:
Fix unit tests to detect import failures

This commit adds onto the existing unit test which simply runs
'testr list-tests' to run discovery on tempest. This is done to ensure
that from a bare tempest repo with the requirements all present we can
actually import and list all the tests. However, there wasn't a check
of the return code. Historically this has been an issue with discovery
failing so adding a check to enforce it moving forward should prevent
it from slipping back in. Part of this is to also fix the test so that
it runs discovery on the correct test suite.

In order to make the unit test pass a config dependency in the
scenario test test_basic_server_ops during the testscenarios call in
load_tests had to be removed. Instead if there is a configuration
error raised while running load tests on this module instead of
failing it will just return the base test class. This is fine
because the test itself will fail on the same configuration
dependencies that load_tests is, however it won't happen silently
during discovery anymore.

Change-Id: Ie74c020de7c9c27adc4ff68dddbae5d4481d1224

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import subprocess from tempest.tests import base class TestImportFailures(base.TestCase): def test_testr_list(self): """Run testr list-tests to check if there are any failures on import""" test_path = os.getenv('OS_TEST_PATH') os.unsetenv('OS_TEST_PATH') self.addCleanup(os.putenv, 'OS_TEST_PATH', test_path) self.assertEqual(0, subprocess.call('testr list-tests', shell=True), "test discovery failed, one or more files cause an " "error on import")

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/134853/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The figure below shows the internals of a message broker node (referred to as a RabbitMQ node in the diagrams) when a single instance is deployed and shared in an OpenStack cloud. Every Nova component connects to the message broker and, depending on its personality (for example a compute node or a network node), may use the queue either as an Invoker (such as API or Scheduler) or a Worker (such as Compute or Network). Invokers and Workers do not actually exist in the Nova object model, but we are going to use them as an abstraction for sake of clarity. An Invoker is a component that sends messages in the queuing system via two operations: 1) rpc.call and ii) rpc.cast; a Worker is a component that receives messages from the queuing system and reply accordingly to rpc.call operations.The diagram below shows the message flow during an rpc.call operation:The diagram below the message flow during an rpc.cast operation:
deleted_lines: The figure below shows the internals of a message broker node (referred to as a RabbitMQ node in the diagrams) when a single instance is deployed and shared in an OpenStack cloud. Every Nova component connects to the message broker and, depending on its personality (for example a compute node or a network node), may use the queue either as an Invoker (such as API or Scheduler) or a Worker (such as Compute or Network). Invokers and Workers do not actually exist in the Nova object model, but we are going to use them as an abstraction for sake of clarity. An Invoker is a component that sends messages in the queuing system via two operations: 1) rpc.call and ii) rpc.cast; a Worker is a component that receives messages from the queuing system and reply accordingly to rcp.call operations.The diagram below shows the message flow during an rp.call operation:The diagram below the message flow during an rp.cast operation:

commit_message:
Fix rule not found error in sec grp default rule API

In V2.1 "os-security-group-default-rules", when default rule is not
found then, DB raise exception - 'SecurityGroupDefaultRuleNotFound'.

Further SecurityGroupAPI->get_all_default_rules() try to catch
'NotFound' exception where it would not be able to catch DB raised
exception because that is derived from 'Invalid' exception.

So during not found situation, SecurityGroupDefaultRulesController
should try to catch 'SecurityGroupDefaultRuleNotFound' instead of
'SecurityGroupNotFound'.

Currently 500 error is thrown in not found case.

This patch also catch those exception in V2 API.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: Ib1c5a02ae19c872afb90e79ad13be8d39394ba97

commit_message:
Cleanup and refactor methods in unit/test_security_groups_rpc

We had strings repeating all along the code which already were
in constant form, those have been refactored. Also global configuration
changes are now handled by functions to enhance code readability.

Change-Id: I0d4e508cda2537abe431f04a278ba2e1d2f5d97d

commit_message:
Include call to delete_subnet from delete_network at DB level

Removes an extra lock in bsn plugin that causes a deadlock
when delete_subnet is invoked form delete_network, agreed
with kevinbenton to remove it
Modifies a unit test to cover this change per reviewer request
Co-author amirosh

Closes-bug: #1197176

Change-Id: Ie3414848a91cc737b16b79399ae19800545e533f

commit_message:
Remove obsolete methods from tempest service client

Commit https://github.com/openstack/manila/commit/2c7595a3
implemented "share servers" approach and removed Manila share-network
activation/deactivation APIs. Manila service client in Tempest plugin was not
updated with this API change and several redundant methods left.

Change-Id: Idd76fed790f8bfc9f7e3502e10dd130bbe5f5bfd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/31/135231/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def action_with_share_network(self, sn_id, action="activate"): """Activates or deactivates share networks. param: sn_id: id of share-network param: action: available values are "activate" and "deactivate" returns: tuple with resp and body of response """ body = json.dumps({action: {}}) uri = "share-networks/%s/action" % sn_id resp, body = self.post(uri, body=body) return resp, self._parse_resp(body) def activate_share_network(self, sn_id): return self.action_with_share_network(sn_id, "activate") def deactivate_share_network(self, sn_id): return self.action_with_share_network(sn_id, "deactivate") def wait_for_share_network_status(self, sn_id, status="active"): """Waits for a Share network to reach a given status.""" __, body = self.get_share_network(sn_id) sn_name = body['name'] sn_status = body['status'].lower() start = int(time.time()) while sn_status != status: time.sleep(self.build_interval) __, body = self.get_share_network(sn_id) sn_status = body['status'].lower() if 'error' in sn_status: # Error can be set only on attempt to activate raise share_exceptions.\ ShareNetworkActivationFailed(sn_id=sn_id) if int(time.time()) - start >= self.build_timeout: message = ('Share-network %s failed to reach %s status within ' 'the required time (%s s).' % (sn_name, status, self.build_timeout)) raise exceptions.TimeoutException(message)

commit_message:
Remove templatedir directive from puppet.conf

Debian-based packaging adds a templatedir parameter to puppet.conf
This is deprecated in puppet and hence adds a lot of deprecated warning
clutter/spam when running the integration tests.

Change-Id: Ie929328cbd7f1231f716cd468887aa579dbe2a07
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceph refs/changes/62/135362/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-2566 shell(:command => 'sed -i "/templatedir/d" /etc/puppet/puppet.conf', :node => vm)

commit_message:
Handle DBConnectionError instead of Exception

Handle database connection error exception instead of
general during reporting Cinder service status to database.

Change-Id: Id292f2ac92c45aa070727890f8d1472b3bb9357d

subject: Have prop attribute access return None by default
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-14 19:45:06.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/resource.py', 'openstack/tests/test_resource.py', 'openstack/network/v2/security_group.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/commit/f9cfb043cf225ed2f66d6ecf44df734b4a7f9d69', 'message': "Have prop attribute access return None by default

resource.prop.__get__ raising an AttributeError as a default value leads
to some interesting code on the user end. An example is in our own code,
in the SecurityGroup initializer, where we try to look into
security_group_rule to convert them from raw data to SecurityGroupRule
objects. That whole loop is wrapped in a try/except for AttributeError,
which would pick up more than the issue of an unset security_group_rule
object, and is not entirely friendly.

Return None as a default value for unset properties. This makes using
them and checking if they've been set much more simple, rather than
having to wrap a lot of your app code in checks for AttributeError.

Change-Id: Iee3e62c10eaed7ecb1a4a882864cc3dd81ad227c
"}]
commit_message:
Have prop attribute access return None by default

resource.prop.__get__ raising an AttributeError as a default value leads
to some interesting code on the user end. An example is in our own code,
in the SecurityGroup initializer, where we try to look into
security_group_rule to convert them from raw data to SecurityGroupRule
objects. That whole loop is wrapped in a try/except for AttributeError,
which would pick up more than the issue of an unset security_group_rule
object, and is not entirely friendly.

Return None as a default value for unset properties. This makes using
them and checking if they've been set much more simple, rather than
having to wrap a lot of your app code in checks for AttributeError.

Change-Id: Iee3e62c10eaed7ecb1a4a882864cc3dd81ad227c

commit_message:
TgtAdm: Don't change CHAP username/password on live migration

As tgtd doesn't update CHAP username/password while the initiator is
connected, CHAP username/password must not be changed while a Nova
instance are performing live-migration; otherwise the compute node
which the instance migrates to cannot login to the volume and the
migration process is aborted.

This fixes TgtAdm implementation not to regenerate random
username/password every time initialize_connection is called.
Also, it enables CHAP auth in unit tests of TargetAdmin helpers.

Change-Id: I48729a33fada62a7c8e4fe500b1e39533d898701
Closes-Bug: #1383509

commit_message:
Add QoS, media affinity and thin allocation support to X-IO volume driver

Enhancements to X-IO volume driver to support extra-specs
and qos-specs. Supported specs will cover QoS IOPSmin, IOPSmax,
IOPSburst, affinity, thin.

Blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/xio-volume-driver-1-1

Dependency:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/xio-iscsi-fc-volume-driver

Change-Id: I9a59ef5b9b45ae9d597f80328b702d6342abb36f
Implements: blueprint xio-volume-driver-1-1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/18/134018/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================================================== Add QoS, media affinity and thin allocation support to X-IO volume driver ========================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/xio-volume-driver-1-1 This blueprint covers enhancements of X-IO volume driver to add support for: - QoS specs - add ability to pass down IOPSmin, IOPSmax and IOPSburst to ISE storage system. - Media affinity - add ability to pass down requested media type for volume. Media types supported: Flash, CADP (hybrid) and HDD only. - Add support for volume retype. - Thin allocation support. Problem description =================== QoS support: Allow the end user to specify IOPSmin, IOPSmax and IOPSburst for a volume. Affinity support: Allow the end user to specify media type for volume. Volume retype support: Allow the end user to change the volume type for an existing volume. The volume will be updated to align with the new type accordingly. Thin allocation support: Allow the end user to specify that the volume should be thinly allocated. Proposed change =============== Extra specs and QoS specs for the specified volume type will be parsed and passed to the ISE storage system as part of the REST call to create volume. Retype will use modify volume REST command to change volume attributes on ISE volume. Extra-specs: Affinity:Type - specifies media type. Valid options: flash, cadp, hdd. Example: To create volume type for flash media type. cinder type-create flash Affinity:Type=flash QoS-specs: QoS:IOPSmax - specifies max IOPS. QoS:IOPSmin - specifies min IOPS. QoS:IOPSburst - specifies burst IOPS. Alloc:Type - specifies allocation type. Valid options: thin, thick. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None. Changes are local to X-IO volume driver. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None. Existing cinderclient commands are used to create volume-types that specifies QoS, affinity. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None. See above for new spec options supported. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: richard-hedlind Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Affinity support: Rework driver to support extra-specs in create_volume API. Affinity attribute will be copied from source volume in case of clone. Implementation complete. QoS support: Rework driver to support qos-specs in create_volume API. Implemented. QoS attributes will be copied from source volume in case of clone. Implementation complete. Retype: Add retype API to driver. API uses REST API modify volume to change attributes for existing volume. Implementation complete. Thin allocation: Pass down thin allocation flag if ISE storage array has support for it. Implementation in progress. Additional unit tests: Add unit tests to test out APIs for affinity, qos, retype, thin. Implementation in progress. Dependencies ============ Dependent on approval of base version of X-IO volume driver: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/xio-iscsi-fc-volume-driver https://review.openstack.org/#/c/116186/ Testing ======= Test using existing test infrastructure according to driver submission steps. Tests will be added to test_xio.py to cover affinity, qos, retype and thin. Documentation Impact ==================== Support Matrix needs to be updated to include X-IO support. https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CinderSupportMatrix Block storage documentation needs to be updated to include X-IO volume driver information in the volume drivers section. http://docs.openstack.org/ References ========== None

commit_message:
Correctly stop functional servers

When running integration tests, the test suite starts real zaqar
servers. The tearDown class was not stopping those servers correctly,
which made the test suite re-use server instances when that was not
necessary, causing other tests to fail.

Change-Id: Ie701a8a609f8661c3607890c4b1b37ab110b155b
Closes-bug: #1383604

commit_message:
Specs for flavors per datastore

Change-Id: I0dfc190110f8461b5f9f325ea2b5c8a965c6d544
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/28/135128/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. ============================================ Associate instance flavors with datastores ============================================ Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/associate-flavors-datastores Motivation: Each datastore type has its own hardware requirements (minimum and maximum). Currently, trove lacks the ability to enforce this requirement. This change enables trove with the ability to associate the virtual hardware templates (flavors) with datastore types. Problem description =================== Trove supports multiple datastore types. However, each datastore type has its own hardware requirements, which presently, cannot be enforced in trove. For example: MySQL - Minimum System Requirements: - 2 or more CPU cores - 2 or more GB of RAM - Disk I/O subsystem applicable for a write-intensive database Find more information about other datastore specific hardware requirements in the References section. Trove uses virtual hardware templates called 'flavors' in OpenStack. In order for trove to be able to enforce the datastore specific hardware requirements, there needs to be a way in which datastore types can be associated with their minimum flavor (hardware) requirements. This way, the user/administrator can at least be notified while provisioning the datastore with the inappropriate flavor, that does not meet the minimum hardware requirements. Proposed change =============== - The trove-manage utility will provide the ability: - to add and delete the datastore version-flavor associations. - There will be an additional API call in order to get a list of flavors for the specified datastore version id. Configuration ------------- None Database -------- No impact on existing tables. One new entity will be created in the trove database: datastore_version_metadata. This will store any additional metadata related to a datastore version including its relation with flavors: key=flavor and the value=flavor_id. The blueprint specifies the table attributes in detail. Public API ---------- Does not impact any other API which the user has access to. Internal API ------------ None Guest Agent ----------- None Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- - Launchpad: riddhi89 - IRC: Riddhi - Email: ridhi.j.shah@gmail.com Milestones ---------- Kilo-1 Work Items ---------- - Add the new database schema for datastore version metadata. - trove-manage util extension to associate a flavor list with a datastore version id - trove-manage util extension to delete a flavor associated with a datastore version id. - REST API call to list flavors for a datastore version id (/{tenant_id}/flavors/{datastore_version_id}) - Unit and integration tests Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= - Unit tests for individual components. - Integration tests for end-to-end testing. Documentation Impact ==================== - New API call to list flavors given a datastore version id. - trove-manage util extensions to add/delete datastore version - flavor associations. References ========== * Further hardware requirements for different datastore types: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TroveFlavorsPerDatastore

commit_message:
Add Werkzeug>=0.7 to global-requirements.txt

Werkzeug>=0.7 is a direct dependency of Designate, and a transitive
dependency of the Flask WSGI framework used by Designate and
Ceilometer.

Werkzeug is a stable + actively maintained collection of WSGI
utilities, providing the basis for the Flask WSGI framework. The
codebase supports Python 2.6, 2.7 and 3.3, is licenced under
the BSD licnese, and is packaged on Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora.

Change-Id: I955dc03010c9988f0dc989217c5c084eede34fb5

commit_message:
Use addCleanup when running swift scenario tests

Helper methods that create containers or objects are now responsible
for providing insurance that the container and object are removed.
delete_wrapper is used so that test cases may choose to delete objects
themselves and the resulting failure to cleanup in addCleanup will
not be an error.

Because deletion is a reasonable "basic op" scenario, the deletion
tests in test_swift_basic_ops are updated so they explicitly
validate deletion while also using addCleanup as a safety measure in
the event the test has unexpected failures.

Change-Id: I70b7172e9485cbd1eb881db3b2add3860da0935a

commit_message:
RandomString don't skip superclass validation

Ensure the superclass validation happens as well as the class-local
additional stuff.

Change-Id: I3fdc6e5d6a4ca741cdd12ca0ed6ceb908c03ae9f
Closes-Bug: #1392754

commit_message:
Remove rackspace/centos7 work-around

The current centos 7 images from rackspace do not have cloud-init
installed via pip, so this is no longer needed.  This work around is
actually a little wrong too, see the bug.

Change-Id: I6642593ca2248d9e01f653cc8e70c70ba8372e50
Partial-bug: #1393073

commit_message:
Remove commented out codes and files related to upgrade-packages

This commit removes some unnecessary commented out codes and files they
are related to upgrade-packages. Upgrading package was part of the
original vision of Grenade. However the scope of upgrades was cut back
now. Because any package upgrades required should be handled in the
service that requires them as Dean Troyer said.

Change-Id: Ic1b6ee2e2b668c0c76c2a1425475651bf8a8bd73

commit_message:
Cleanup docs - raises class

The argument to the :raises: directive is the class name. If the
class name is a valid reference it's rendered as a link to the
class. This change cleans up the :raises: directives to use the
reference correctly and use a valid class reference.

Change-Id: I84188b60de0ab4c6b5b2fb5a203c43bfde094707
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/58/127858/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :raises keystoneclient.exceptions.ClientException: For connection failure, or to indicate an error response code. :raises keystoneclient.exceptions.AuthorizationFailure: if a new token fetch fails. :raises keystoneclient.exceptions.MissingAuthPlugin: if a plugin is not available.
deleted_lines: :raises exceptions.ClientException: For connection failure, or to indicate an error response code. :raises AuthorizationFailure: if a new token fetch fails. :raises MissingAuthPlugin: if a plugin is not available.

commit_message:
Updated to start metadata-api

This should also be ported to stable/icehouse

This starts the nova-metadata-api service on the compute
nodes when nova-networking is leveraged. This does not effect
neutron.

Change-Id: Id0a654bbe20cebb8f0f9ba38c7e132badfb2f06e

commit_message:
Add a reverse name columns to domains/recordsets

Adds 'reverse_name' columns to domains and recordsets
tables. Should vastly improve superdomain checks and filtering
of domains and recordsets by name.

Change-Id: I2e1587bbc6d9dfa0690b2568fe44f91688e5495e

added_lines: <section xml:id="section_telemetry-alarm-workload-partitioning"> <title>Workload partitioning</title> <para>The alarm evaluation process uses the same mechanism for workload partitioning as the central and compute agents. The <link xlink:href="https://pypi.python.org/pypi/tooz"> Tooz</link> library provides the coordination within the groups of service instances. For further information about this approach see the <xref linkend="section_telemetry-cetral-compute-agent-ha"/>. </para> <para>To use this workload partitioning solution, set the <option>evaluation_service</option> option to <literal> default</literal>. For more information, see the alarm section in the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/ch_configuring-openstack-telemetry.html"> <citetitle>OpenStack Configuration Reference</citetitle> </link>.</para> </section>

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/65/130865/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============== Authentication ============== OpenStackClient leverages Keystone client's authentication plugins to support a number of different authentication methods. Authentication Process ---------------------- The user provides some number of authentication credential options. If an authentication type is not provided (``-os-auth-type``), the authentication options are examined to determine if one of the default types can be used. If no match is found an error is reported and OSC exits. Note that the authentication call to the Identity service has not yet occurred. It is deferred until the last possible moment in order to reduce the number of unnecessary queried to the server, such as when further processing detects an invalid command. Authentication Plugins ---------------------- Keystone client contains a base set of plugins, additional ones may be available from the Keystone project or other sources. The description of the plugins themselves is found in the Keysotne documentation. There are at least three authentication types that are always available: * **Password**: A username and password, plus optional project and/or domain, are used to identify the user. This is the most common type and is the default any time a username is supplied. An authentication URL for the Identity service is also required. [Required: ``--os-auth-url``, ``--os-project-name``, ``--os-username``; Optional: ``--os-password``] * **Token**: This is slightly different from the usual token authentication (described below as token/endpoint) in that a token and an authentication URL are supplied and the plugin retrieves a new (scoped?) token. [Required: ``--os-auth-url``, ``--os-token``] * **Token/Endpoint**: This is the original token authentication (known as 'token flow' in the early CLI documentation in the OpenStack wiki). It requires a token and a direct endpoint that is used in the API call. The difference from the new Token type is this token is used as-is, no call is made to the Identity service from the client. This type is most often used to bootstrap a Keystone server where the token is the ``admin_token`` configured in ``keystone.conf``. It will also work with other services and a regular scoped token such as one obtained from a ``token issue`` command. [Required: ``--os-url``, ``--os-token``] * **Others**: There are SAML and other (Kerberos?) plugins under development that are also supported. To use them they must be selected by supplying the ``auth-type`` options. Detailed Process ---------------- The authentication process in OpenStackClient is all contained in and handled by the ``ClientManager`` object. * On import ``api.auth``: * obtains the list of installed Keystone authentication plugins from the ``keystoneclient.auth.plugin`` entry point. * builds a list of authentication options from the plugins. * A new ``ClientManager`` is created and supplied with the set of options from the command line and/or environment: * If ``--os-auth-type`` is not provided select an authentication plugin based on the existing options. This is a short-circuit evaluation, the first match wins. * if ``--os-auth-type`` is supplied and a valid and available plugin it is used * if ``--os-endpoint`` and ``--os-token`` are supplied ``token_endpoint`` is selected * if ``--os-username`` is supplied ``password`` is selected * if ``--os-token`` is supplied ``token`` is selected * if no selection has been made by now exit with error * Load the selected plugin class. * When an operation that requires authentication is attempted ``ClientManager`` makes the actual inital request to the Identity service. * if ``--os-auth-url`` is not supplied for any of the types except Token/Endpoint, exit with an error.

subject: Check server group policy on migrate/evacuate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-18 16:39:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b1a5aad3453a486ec34b24bb22e66332f90f1b04', 'message': "Check server group policy on migrate/evactuate

This patch changes server group checking in the instance group setup.
Previously, it checked for the presence of the 'group' scheduler hint
as an indication that the instance was a member of a group.  However,
that hint is only present on initial boot.  It is not present when the
scheduler is being used to pick a destination for a migration or
evactuate.

The updated logic checks the database to see if the instance is a
member of a group.  For performance reasons, it only does this is
server group functionality is enabled in the scheduler (group filters
are enabled).

This change makes it so server group policy enforcement will still
occur for migrations and evactuations, instead of only on first boot.

It also adds the call to setup_instance_group in evacuate, resize,
cold migrate and live migrate methods because now it is possible to
access the group setup.

Implements blueprint anti-affinity-on-migration

Closes-bug: #1379451

Change-Id: If17ff56d9601e2d126c158d2d9eb36ac3ac5878f
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-11-18 16:40:54.000000000', 'files': ['nova/scheduler/utils.py', 'nova/tests/unit/conductor/test_conductor.py', 'nova/conductor/manager.py', 'nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py', 'nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_scheduler_utils.py', 'nova/tests/unit/conductor/tasks/test_live_migrate.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9920f548164a8b462f0a6907ef1da66db3207710', 'message': "Check server group policy on migrate/evacuate

This patch changes server group checking in the instance group setup.
Previously, it checked for the presence of the 'group' scheduler hint
as an indication that the instance was a member of a group.  However,
that hint is only present on initial boot.  It is not present when the
scheduler is being used to pick a destination for a migration or
evactuate.

The updated logic checks the database to see if the instance is a
member of a group.  For performance reasons, it only does this is
server group functionality is enabled in the scheduler (group filters
are enabled).

This change makes it so server group policy enforcement will still
occur for migrations and evactuations, instead of only on first boot.

It also adds the call to setup_instance_group in evacuate, resize,
cold migrate and live migrate methods because now it is possible to
access the group setup.

Implements blueprint anti-affinity-on-migration

Closes-bug: #1379451

Change-Id: If17ff56d9601e2d126c158d2d9eb36ac3ac5878f
"}]
commit_message:
Check server group policy on migrate/evacuate

This patch changes server group checking in the instance group setup.
Previously, it checked for the presence of the 'group' scheduler hint
as an indication that the instance was a member of a group.  However,
that hint is only present on initial boot.  It is not present when the
scheduler is being used to pick a destination for a migration or
evactuate.

The updated logic checks the database to see if the instance is a
member of a group.  For performance reasons, it only does this is
server group functionality is enabled in the scheduler (group filters
are enabled).

This change makes it so server group policy enforcement will still
occur for migrations and evactuations, instead of only on first boot.

It also adds the call to setup_instance_group in evacuate, resize,
cold migrate and live migrate methods because now it is possible to
access the group setup.

Implements blueprint anti-affinity-on-migration

Closes-bug: #1379451

Change-Id: If17ff56d9601e2d126c158d2d9eb36ac3ac5878f

commit_message:
Remove check of verification smoke tests

Smoke tests are broken and this check is blocker for all rally changes,
so we should disable it.

commit_message:
ML2 Cisco Nexus Mechanism Driver VxLAN Gateway Support

This spec describes the work being done by the blueprint
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-cisco-nexus-mechdriver-vxlan
which implements VXLAN support for the Cisco Nexus switches.

Change-Id: I0249729520ebeda1288eb188743ac4b98c48693e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/77/98177/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================================== ML2 Cisco Nexus Mechanism Driver VXLAN Gateway Support ====================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-cisco-nexus-mechdriver-vxlan This blueprint is to implement VXLAN support for the Cisco Nexus switches. Problem description =================== In general, a VXLAN topology lets you create a Layer 2 network on top of a Layer 3 network using VXLAN encapsulation. This allows a network admin to increase the number of entities you can connect up to about 16 million. The blueprint is being used for adding ML2 cisco_nexus mechanism driver control plane code to program the Nexus switches for VXLAN functionality. Topology supported with this code is: [host] <- VLAN traffic -> [nexus switch] <- VXLAN traffic -> {IPv4 network} The traffic from the host system to the nexus switch will be VLAN and then encapsulated/decapsulated by the nexus switch to VXLAN formatting. The device responsible for VXLAN encap/decap is called a VTEP (VXLAN Tunnel End Point). Proposed change =============== A Cisco nexus switch has three sets of commands for configuring VXLAN: (1) Enabling VXLAN (2) Mapping VLAN to VXLAN VNI (Virtual Network Identifier) (3) Creating and Configuring an NVE (Network Virtualization Endpoint) overlay interface which is used to terminate VXLAN tunnels. For configuration item (1) these sets of commands are executed only once. Therefore these actions will be performed at initialization of the cisco_nexus mechanism driver (MD). Configuration item (2) consists of mapping the VLAN to the VNI. The current cisco_nexus MD supports the creation of the vlan interface. This configure action is triggered by create/update port events. The event will also trigger the configuration of the "vn-segment" keyword on the vlan interface. For (3) new VXLAN related variables will be introduced to the [cisco] section of the ml2_conf_cisco.ini file. An example of these variables is listed in the example below. It is expected that the bind_port() event will trigger the action to configure the nexus switch. Expected VXLAN syntax changes for [cisco] example: [cisco] nve_src_intf=loopback1 nve_mcast_group=230.1.1.1 Where the new vxlan variables are defined as: nve_src_intf = NVE (Network Virtualization Edge) source interface. The source interface must be a loopback interface that is configured on the switch with a valid /32 IP address. This /32 IP address must be known by the transient devices in the transport network and the remote VTEPs. This is accomplished by advertising it through a dynamic routing protocol in the transport network. nve_mcast_group = multicast group address to be used for the VNI. Note that in addition to the VXLAN specific configuration listed above that additional configuration (PIM, OSPF, loopback address, etc. ) is required on the nexus switch for VXLAN support. This configuration is outside the scope of this blueprint. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- The column "vnid" will be added to the existing ML2 cisco_nexus database table "cisco_ml2_nexusport_bindings". Migration file will be updated accordingly. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Minimal. Additional database access and control plane processing under the ML2 cisco_nexus MD. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Rich Curran <rcurran> Work Items ---------- - VxLAN control plane code added to ML2 cisco_nexus MD. - VxLAN ML2 cisco_nexus unit tests. Dependencies ============ ML2 Type drivers refactor to allow extensiblity - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/91811 ML2 Custom type driver - Design spec not defined yet. ML2 Hierarchical Port Binding - Design spec not defined yet. Testing ======= Complete unit test coverage of the code is included. For tempest test coverage, third party testing is provided. The Cisco CI reports on all changes affecting this driver. The testing is run in a setup with an OpenStack deployment (devstack) connected to a Cisco Nexus 5K physical switch. Documentation Impact ==================== Deployment documentation on how to configure and deploy this feature will be documented in the Openstack wiki. References ========== ML2 Cisco Nexus MD WIKI: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/ML2/MechCiscoNexus

commit_message:
multi-node dg setup

Adding intial support for multi-node devstack jobs,
by using the nodepool's subnode feature.

TODO: remove extra set -x
TODO: Use the feature grid
TODO: improve logging

Change-Id: I37fb0924be1676be1a1e301094b6e5a4cd348969
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/43/106043/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function remote_command { local ssh_opts="-o PasswordAuthentication=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o ConnectionAttempts=4" local dest_host=$1 shift ssh $ssh_opts $dest_host "$@" } function remote_copy_dir { local dest_host=$1 local src_dir=$2 local dest_dir=$3 remote_command "$dest_host" mkdir -p "$dest_dir" rsync -avz "$src_dir" "${dest_host}:$dest_dir" } function remote_copy_file { local ssh_opts="-o PasswordAuthentication=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o ConnectionAttempts=4" local src=$1 local dest=$2 shift scp $ssh_opts "$src" "$dest" } function get_nodepool_role { cat /etc/nodepool/role } # TODO(afazekas): remove the not enabled part form COMPUTE_SERVICE_SET # NOTE(afazekas): fully supporting n-net would be challenging, # 1. 'flat' because of the metadata-api and dhcp service ip collusion issues # 2. 'lb' providing trunk ports to the test VMs COMPUTE_SERVICE_SET="n-cpu,q-agt,ceilometer-acompute" local role=`get_nodepool_role` if [ $role = sub ]; then NODE_ENABLED_SERVICES=$COMPUTE_SERVICE_SET else NODE_ENABLED_SERVICES=$MY_ENABLED_SERVICES fi ENABLED_SERVICES=$NODE_ENABLED_SERVICES if [ "$role" = sub ]; then local primary_node=`cat /etc/nodepool/primary_node` if [[ $MY_ENABLED_SERVICES =~ "qpid" ]]; then echo "QPID_HOST=$primary_node" >>localrc fi if [[ $MY_ENABLED_SERVICES =~ "rabbit" ]]; then echo "RABBIT_HOST=$primary_node" >>localrc fi echo "DATABASE_HOST=$primary_node" >>localrc echo "GLANCE_HOSTPORT=$primary_node:9292" >>localrc echo "Q_HOST=$primary_node" >>localrc echo "KEYSTONE_SERVICE_HOST=$primary_node" >>localrc fi

commit_message:
Custom variables

This feature enables a user to upload custom variables to Solum.
User can access the variables through test scripts and applications.

Change-Id: I0a8038db1a0c084a102dd5fa5b11d10aa29e189f

commit_message:
Remove 55672 from reserved ports

Remove rabbitmq 55672 from reserved ports
as it is not being used in rabbitmq v3.0+
and change 55672 to 15672 in zabbix files

Change-Id: Ie18b6a838358192f6cd0ed9c07d5de66002da684
Closes-Bug: 1393407
(cherry picked from commit 76b2d666f6272dfbfdabcc252d55d98be8a1f900)

commit_message:
Change name new_name generation

Change new_name generation in test_rename_environment
test. Fix dvsm job. Recently new env validation
was appeared in murano api. sometimes uuid.uuid4().hex
generate string which starts from the digit.
it is incorrect for murano api validation

Change-Id: I9d97e4a4a9023dca0b128f364314f2ba405e7de8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/01/134901/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: new_name = "gg" + uuid.uuid4().hex

commit_message:
Filter out some Tempest tests for Nova cells

We would like to get a set of Tempest tests running against Nova cells
that is expected to pass given the current functionality provided.
This is being done via regexes so that we can spend the bulk of our
effort on cellsv2 and put the current cells feature into maintenance
mode quickly.

Change-Id: I0c6047ca66d4d740f8ca0bc67a258bb36db8dbfe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/64/135064/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Construct a regex to use when limiting scope of tempest # to avoid features unsupported by Nova Cells. r="^(?!.*" # skip security group tests r="$r(?:tempest\.api\.compute\.security_groups.*)" # skip aggregates tests r="$r|(?:tempest\.api\.compute\.admin\.test_aggregates*)|(?:tempest\.scenario\.test_aggregates_basic_ops*)" # skip availability zone tests r="$r|(?:(tempest\.api\.compute\.)(servers\.|admin\.)(test_availability_zone*))" r="$r).*$" export DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_REGEX="$r"

commit_message:
Remove -full designation from cells job

In preparation for paring down the tests that the cells job runs it has
been renamed without the -full designation.  There was an existing cells
job of that name which was unused and it has been removed.

Change-Id: I6c1448c12904c3b4921a7a6668d46711c1417dce

commit_message:
Can't Access Default Pool through API

  Since the default pool had a tenant_id = Null, not even an
  admin could access it through the API. This fixes that.

  Closes-Bug:#1392748

Change-Id: I5238b119ee62dc168ac3bfc5875619c1e07eac60

commit_message:
Drop Python 3.3 tests in tox

We don't care about it anymore, we have Python 3.4

commit_message:
Initial commit from github (squashed)

These were the commits from github repo(s)

  84d943e Initial commit
  3d15bd1 Created the pecan project for containers for API
  b49297b Added rest functionality to the v2 apis
  227e1dd Added rest functionality to the v2 apis
  39500ae Added the base API call like POST, GET, PUT & DELETE.
  e404e94 adding wsme support to pecan
  f90f540 Added wsme support to the magnum apis
  c879329 added changes to api
  24ebc32 Fixed the bugs in the container apis
  01725ef Rename dir from containers to magnum
  1a1375a Add requirements and test-requirements
  f957e2e Add ASL2.0 license
  8f4c0ee Move tests to the proper location
  48dd100 Move setup files to proper directory
  86cc435 Fix the setup so the installation is sanitary
  b766d59 Make the installation and tox testing work
  c477236 This is a new project - start with v1 for api
  cf20cac Remove pep8 errors
  d23b325 Merge with code generated using OpenStack cookie-cutter
  b6b9f34 Ability to run pecan serve from command line

Had to update requirements.txt to get jobs working

Change-Id: I068389412d023c258bda40dfbdff5a40f2e7d175
Co-Authored-By: Digambar Patil <digambarpat@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Steven Dake <sdake@redhat.com>
